etymologies: Middle English (originally as used in the game of chess): the noun and exclamation from Old French eschec, from medieval Latin scaccus, via Arabic from Persian šāh ‘king’; the verb from Old French eschequier ‘play chess, put in check’. The sense ‘stop or control’ arose from the use in chess, and led (in the late 17th century) to ‘examine the accuracy of’

definitions: examine (something) in order to determine its accuracy, quality, or condition, or to detect the presence of something

examples.text: customs officers have the right to check all luggage
a simple blood test to check for anemia

definitions: verify or establish to one's satisfaction

examples.text: she glanced over her shoulder to check that the door was shut
check the expiration date on your passport

definitions: verify the accuracy of something by comparing it with (something else)

examples.text: keep your receipt to check against your statement

shortDefinitions: test accuracy of one thing against another

definitions: inspect or examine thoroughly

examples.text: I checked through my notes

definitions: agree or correspond when compared.
look at; take notice of

examples.text: check the remix

definitions: stop or slow down the progress of (something undesirable)

examples.text: efforts were made to check the disease

definitions: curb or restrain (a feeling or emotion)

examples.text: he learned to check his excitement

definitions: hamper or neutralize (an opponent) with one's body or stick.
provide a means of preventing

examples.text: processes to check against deterioration in the quality of the data held

definitions: (of a passenger) consign (baggage) to the care of the transport provider with whom they are traveling

examples.text: I checked my bag and got my boarding pass

shortDefinitions: consign baggage to care of one's transport provider

definitions: deposit (a coat, bag, or other item) for temporary safekeeping in the cloakroom of a restaurant, theater, etc.

examples.text: the drinks weren't expensive and there's no cover charge but you do have to check your coat for $3.00

shortDefinitions: deposit item for temporary safekeeping in cloakroom of restaurant, theatre, etc.

definitions: mark or click on (a box) in order to select a particular option on a form, questionnaire, etc.

examples.text: users who want privacy should check the box that prevents your files from being shared

shortDefinitions: mark or click on box to select option

definitions: move a piece or pawn so that (the opposing king) is under attack

examples.text: he moves his knight to check my king again

definitions: (in poker) choose not to make a bet when called upon, allowing the action to move to another player.
shortDefinitions: (in poker) choose not to make bet

definitions: (of a hound) pause to make sure of or regain a scent.
(of a trained hawk) abandon the intended quarry and fly after other prey.
an examination to test or ascertain accuracy, quality, or satisfactory condition

examples.text: a campaign calling for regular checks on gas appliances
a health check

definitions: a stopping or slowing of progress

examples.text: there was no check to the expansion of the market

definitions: a means of control or restraint

examples.text: a permanent check upon the growth or abuse of central authority

definitions: an act of hampering or neutralizing an opponent with one's body or stick.
a temporary loss of the scent in hunting.
a false stoop when a hawk abandons its intended quarry and pursues other prey.
a move by which a piece or pawn directly attacks the opponent's king. If the defending player cannot counter the attack, the king is checkmated.
a written order to a bank to pay a stated sum from the drawer's account

examples.text: he was awarded a check for $1,000

shortDefinitions: written order to bank to pay stated sum

definitions: the bill in a restaurant

examples.text: let's get the check

definitions: a token of identification for left luggage.
a counter used as a stake in a gambling game.
a part of a piano that catches the hammer and prevents it from retouching the strings.
a crack or flaw in timber.
expressing assent or agreement.
used by a chess player to announce that the opponent's king has been placed in check.

etymologies: late Middle English: probably from chequer (sense 1 of the noun)

definitions: a pattern of small squares

examples.text: a fine black-and-white check

definitions: a garment or fabric with a pattern of small squares

examples.text: on Wednesdays he wore the small check

shortDefinitions: garment or fabric with pattern of small squares

definitions: having a pattern of small squares

examples.text: a blue check T-shirt

etymologies: early 18th century (originally denoting a counterfoil, or a form with a counterfoil): variant of check, in the sense ‘device for checking the amount of an item’

crossReferenceMarkers: British spelling of check (sense 4 of the noun)
shortDefinitions: order to bank to pay sum from drawer's account
